questions.text: 37 years female unmarried, nulliparous having regular intercourse, but on OCPs mother had carcinoma at 50 years of age. Sister had cancer at 40 years of age. What would you advise as the next step?
questions.solution:
The family history depicts a strong correlation for breast cancer among the given primary relatives and as she is less than age of 50 she is considered to be High risk of breast cancer.

The next line of management should be genetic counseling and screening for BRCA.

Genetic counseling and counseling should be done for all the high risk individuals. Genetic counseling should be done for mutations like BRCA 1, BRCA 2, PTEN, TP53 etc

Models used for categorising high risk patients for breast carcinoma:

  • Gail model- assesses population risk using nongenetic factors,
  • Claus model-provides individual estimates of breast cancer risk according to decade of life based on knowledge of first-degree and second-degree relatives with breast cancer and their ages at diagnosis.
  • Couch model-predicts the risk for mutation in BRCA1 gene

Screening for high risk patients: MRI is used and screening started at the age of 30 years

If BRCA1 gene positive then the patient should under go bilateral prophylactic mastectomy + bilateral salphingo ophorectecomy

INDICATIONS FOR CONSIDERATION OF GENETIC TESTING

  • Include breast cancer diagnosed before age 50
  • Bilateral breast cancer
  • Breast and ovarian cancer in the same individual
  • Breast cancer in men
  • Other factors that may be indications for testing
  • Are a family history (maternal or paternal) of 2 or more individuals with breast and ovarian cancer
  • A close male relative with breast cancer
  • A close relative with early onset (<50 years) breast or ovarian cancer
  • Known BRCA1 or BRCA2 mutation in the family

questions.text: 30 male blunt injuries to the abdomen. There was no blood at the tip of meatus. Nil urine output after Foley's catheterization. The next best management for the patient?
questions.solution:
Given clinical blunt injury to the abdomen and no blood at meatus plus almost no urine output after foley's catheter suggests intraperitoneal bladder rupture.

The absence of blood at meatus rules out urethral injury

so the next  definitive step in management would be laparotomy.

Bladder trauma:

Extraperitoneal bladder rupture: the peritoneum is intact and urine extravasates into the retropubic space but not into the peritoneal cavity, occurs most commonly following a pelvic fracture

Intraperitoneal bladder rupture: the peritoneum over the bladder is injured and urine extravasates into the peritoneal cavity) or mixed. Intraperitoneal ruptures are associated with a risk of urinary peritonitis and ileus, and so are more signifcant than extraperitoneal ruptures. Occurs mostly due to iatrogenic during gynaecological procedure.

Investigation:

Retrograde cystogram or CT cystogram confrms the diagnosis and identifes whether the injury is intraperitoneal or extraperitoneal

Management bladder injury:

Extraperitoneal injury can be managed with indwelling catheterisation for 10-14 days

Intraperitoneal injury most often requires laparotomy and repair of the bladder defect

Option a) SPC (suprapubic catheterisation) done in urethral injury, the above scenario is not an urethral injury, as there is no blood at tip of meatus, no SPC not done

choices.text: Primary contraction more with full thickness grafts
Secondary contraction more with full thickness grafts

questions.text: The correct statement is/are regarding the difference between SSG and Full thickness graft?
questions.solution:
Definition skin graft:

Skin harvested from donor site and transferred to recipient site that does not carry its own blood supply

Survival requires generation of new blood vessels from recipient site bed

Classification:

Full thickness vs. split thickness skin grafting

Full thickness = entire epidermis + dermis

Split thickness = epidermis + partial dermis

Types of partial thickness split Greta's:

  • Thin (thiersch-Ollier) - 0.006-0.012 inch thickness
  • Intermediate (Blair and brown): 0.012-0.018 inch thickness
  • Thick (Padgett): 0.018-0.024 inch thickness

questions.text: Nutritional complications are more with which fistula?
questions.solution:
Proximal small intestine fistulas will have high output → so metabolic and electrolyte complications are more common with proximal fistula

The maximum malnutrition is caused by duodenal fistulas.

Although gastric and duodenal fistulas receive almost the same food and enzymes, duodenum receives extra bile from gallbladder and pancreatic enzymes from pancreas hence duodenal fistula are more notorious for nutritional complications.

Fistulas which are difficult to heal:

  • F- foreign body in tract
  • R- radiotherapy
  • I- inflammatory bowel disease
  • E- epithelialised tract
  • N- neoplasia
  • D- distal obstruction
  • S- short fistulous tract (<2.5cm)

Principles of management of enterocutaneous fistula (SNAP)

  • S- elimination of Sepsis and skin protection
  • N- Nutrition - a period of parenteral nutrition may well be required.
  • A- Anatomical assessment
  • P- definitive Planned surgery

questions.text: A 32-year female patient on tamoxifen after a breast cancer surgery. For around 5 years she was on tamoxifen. When will she stop tamoxifen if she wants to conceive?
questions.solution:
TAMOXIFEN is a SERM (selective Estrogen receptor modulator) given for women with ER+ breast cancer for minimum of 5 years, but latest atlas trial advise for 10 years use

During pregnancy, tamoxifen and its metabolites interact with rapidly growing and developing embryonic or fetal tissues.

The relatively high frequency of severe congenital abnormalities indicates that reliable birth control during tamoxifen treatment is mandatory.

After tamoxifen use, a washout period of 1-2 months is advisable based on the known half-life of tamoxifen.

In case of an inadvertent pregnancy, risks and options should be discussed.

Reference: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3233288

questions.text: Identify the specimen shown below:
questions.solution:
The given image shows whitish yellow nodules of around 1 mm in the whole bladder suggesting it as Cholesterolosis.

Cholesterolosis (cholesterosis) is characterised by the accumulation of lipids (triglycerides, cholesterol precursors and cholesterol esters) in the mucosa of the gallbladder wall.

The lipid accumulation creates yellow deposits on a background of hyperaemic mucosa ('strawberry gallbladder'). It may be associated with cholesterol stones

questions.text: IOC to diagnose the disease?
questions.solution:
Clinical features such as dysphagia (to both solid and liquid), regurgitation and heartburn are suggestive of achalasia cardia, milder form of which can be often confused with GERD.

The barium swallow shows typical "bird beak sign". Or "rat tail appearance"

Endoscopy typically shows frothy saliva pooling in the oesophagus and the presence of food residue.

Definitive diagnosis relies on HRM(high resolution manometry)

questions.text: Blood from donor in Indian setup is uasually screened for all except:
questions.solution:
• In the UK, up to 450 ml of blood is drawn, a maximum of three times each year .
  • Each unit is tested for evidence of hepatitis B, hepatitis C, HIV 1, HIV 2 and syphilis.
  • Donations are leukodepleted as a precaution against variant CJD (this may also reduce the immunogenencity of the transfusion)
  • In INDIA, it is mandatory to test every unit of blood collected for hepatitis B, hepatitis C, HIV/AIDS, syphilis and malaria

choices.text: Fall in HB from 12 to 10 gm/dl

questions.text: Patient of RTA with grade-3 splenic trauma, on non-operative management in ward. What would be the reason for laparotomy on the second day of management?
questions.solution:
The presence of pneumoperitoneum on imaging would warrant a laparotomy as it suggests visceral perforation which can lead to secondary peritonitis.

upon the extent of injury, spleen rupture is classified into five grades on the basis of CT, which is considered to be the most important investigation for assessment of abdominal trauma in a hemodynamically stable patient

Vigorous resuscitation remains the key to management of blunt trauma.

Splenectomy should be performed for severe grades of injury where control of bleeding takes precedence over measures to salvage the spleen.

Indications of splenectomy in stable patient with splenic trauma

  • Presence of pneumoperitoneum
  • Serial fall in hemoglobin and not a single value fall
  • Patient becomes detiriorated
  • For some other injury

Discharging a patient managed non-operatively for splenic trauma-CECT abdomen to be done before discharging such patient to look for tumor blush (pseudo aneurysm of splenic artery), if present angiocoil embolisation to be done

questions.text: HPV is implicated in all the following except:
questions.solution:
• All the given cancers in the option are associated with HPV of which laryngeal papillomatosis is of lesser incidence with HPV
  • Human Papillomavirus - At least 70 genetically distinct types of HPV have been identified. Some types (e.g., 1, 2, 4, and 7) cause benign squamous papillomas (warts) in humans.
  • In contrast, high-risk HPVs (e.g., types 16 and 18) have been implicated in the genesis of squamous cell carcinomas of the cervix, anogenital region, and head and neck (particularly tumors arising in the tonsillar mucosa).
  • These cancers are sexually transmitted diseases caused by chronic HPV infection. In contrast to cervical cancers, genital warts have low malignant potential and are associated with lowrisk HPVs, predominantly HPV-6 and HPV-11

choices.text: Pain on passive movements of the calf

questions.text: A deep ulcer presented in the figure depicted?
questions.solution:
This is type of pressure ulcer

These begin with tissue necrosis at a pressure point and develop into a cone-shaped volume of necrotic loss

This type of necrosis results in decreased sensations of the ulcer and surrounding areas.

In a patient who has no predisposing factors management is aimed at debridement and repair of the defect, on the assumption that recurrence will not occur once normal function and sensibility returns

Management:

Primary treatment involves relieving pressure (special mattress, nursing care, relief of muscle spasm and contractures), optimising nutrition, correcting anaemia and preventing infection. Surgery involves thorough debridement to promote healing and plastic surgery to reconstruct the defect.

Option a) positive trendelenberg test is associated with venous ulcer and varicose veins

Option d) pain of passive movement of calf muscles is suggestive of DVT

Option c) absent of distal pulses is seen in arterial ulcer due to PVD, ulcer present on the dorsum of foot

questions.text: Which investigations are not commonly used or less significant in the picture depicted?
questions.solution:
The given x-ray of the barium study shows typical Achalasia cardia showing typical bird-beak signs.

The cause is thought to be due to loss of the inhibitory ganglion cells in the myenteric (Auerbach's) plexus, possibly related to a virus-induced autoimmune effect.

Clinical scoring system for achalasia (Eckardt score).

Diagnosis:

Initial identification for milder symptoms can be done with barium study as it typically shows the narrowed OG junction.

Furthermore the diagnosis can be better augmented through endoscopy.

High resolution manometry (HRM) remains the gold standard for the diagnosis, establishing and identifying degree of severity.

However PH monitoring is often advocated in GORD.

questions.text: What cancer is being operated here?
questions.solution:
The given image is of Whipple's procedure otherwise known as pancreaticoduodenectomy.

A Whipple procedure - also known as a pancreaticoduodenectomy - is a complex operation to remove the head of the pancreas, the first part of the small intestine (duodenum), the gallbladder and the bile duct.

The Whipple procedure is used to treat tumors are

  • Periampullary cancer
  • Head of pancreas cancer
  • Duodenal cancer
  • Distal cholangiocarcinoma

Reference: https://www.mayoclinic.org/tests-procedures/whipple-procedure/about/pac-

questions.text:
Most common ectopic tissue found in meckel's diverticulum is/are type?
1.Gastric
2. Colonic
3. Pancreatic
4.Adrenal
questions.solution:
• Meckel's diverticulum is a persistent remnant of the vitellointestinal duct and is present in about 2% of the population.
  • It is found on the antimesenteric side of the ileum approximately 60 cm from the ileocaecal valve and is classically 5 cm long (2% prevalence; 2 feet [60 cm] from ileocaecal valve; 2 inches [5 cm] long).
  • A Meckel's diverticulum is a congenital diverticulum. It contains all three coats of the bowel wall and has its own blood supply. It may be vulnerable to obstruction and infammation in the same way as the appendix;
  • indeed, when a normal appendix is found at surgery for suspected appendicitis, a Meckel's diverticulum should be looked for by examining the small bowel, particularly if free fuid or pus is found.
  • In approximately 20% of cases, the mucosa of a Meckel's diverticulum contains heterotopic epithelium of gastric, colonic or pancreatic type. The presence of heterotopic mucosa may predispose to the development of complications.

The vast majority of Meckel's diverticula are asymptomatic and a Meckel's diverticulum is notoriously difcult to visualise with contrast radiology.

questions.text: A patient developed loss of sensation at the root of penis after laparoscopic hernia surgery. Which of the following nerves would have been damaged?
questions.solution:
The root of the base of penis has innervation from the illiohypogastric nerve.

While passing between the transversus abdominis and internal oblique, the illiohypogastric nerve gives off 2 branches: lateral cutaneous and anterior cutaneous branch

  • Lateral cutaneous branch-supplies the gluteal skin
  • Anterior cutaneous branch supplies surapubic skin
  1. Most common nerve injured in open hernia repair: illioinguinal nerve
  2. Most common nerve injured laparoscopic hernia repair: lateral cutaneous nerve
  3. Most common nerve entrapped in mesh: illiohypogastric nerve
  4. Injury to right illiohypogastric nerve during appendectomy leads to right direct inguinal hernia

Infusion of local anaesthetic may lead to femoral nerve blockade that will resolve over some hours.

choices.text: Pott's spine can present as psoas abscess
Pain during passive extension of hip
Haematogenous spread of TB is immune-compromised.

questions.text: Psoas abscess present as all of the following except?
questions.solution:
Retroperitoneal (psoas) abscess:

  • The psoas abscess is an abscess of the retroperitoneum
  • psoas abscess was mostly found secondary to direct spread of infection from the inflamed digestive or urinary tract with or without perforation, advanced Crohn's disease,
  • It arises due to haematogenous spread from an occult source in immunocompromised patients and in association with intravenous drug misuse.

Clinical features includes:

  • Back pain, lassitude and fever
  • A swelling may point to the groin as it tracks distally along the iliopsoas muscle, under the inguinal ligament.
  • Pain may be elicited by passive extension of the hip or a fixed flexion of the hip evident on inspection.

Diagnosis and treatment:

  • CT scanning and treatment is usually by percutaneous CT-guided drainage and appropriate antibiotic therapy.

The white arrow mark in the image shows right sided Psoas abscess

choices.text: Chrons is mucosal and UC is transmural

questions.text: Mark the wrong statement about IBD
questions.solution:
Management of ulcerative colitis

Most patients are maintained on optimised medical therapy

  • Acute severe colitis (ASC) requires multidisciplinary management
  • Toxic dilatation or impending complication should be suspected if the patient develops abdominal tenderness or distension, or deteriorates clinically
  • Patients with colitis are at increased risk of developing cancer; those with pancolitis of long duration are most at risk

Reference: European consensus on the histopathology of inflammatory bowel disease; Journal of Crohn's and Colitis (2013) 7, 827-85

questions.text: What is the correct volume of the prostate
questions.solution:
The prostate gland lies between the bladder neck and the urogenital diaphragm, just anterior to the rectum, an ideal position to be imaged via TRUS

The normal prostate gland has measures 3 × 3 × 5 cm approximately or a volume of 20 ml.

Mc NEAL surgical zones of prostate:

  • Peripheral zone: most common site for cancer prostate
  • Transitional zone: most common site for BPH, TURP involves corring of transitional zone

Reference: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC2842183/#:~:text=The%20 prostate%20is%20 further%20 divided,a%20 volume%20 of%2025%20ml.

choices.text: FNAC or biopsy required before surgery
Leakage of the cyst can cause anaphylaxis.

questions.text: Hydatid cyst of kidney image given. State the wrong one
questions.solution:
The given CT SCAN shows multiple hydatid cyst in kidney parenchyma suggestive of Human echinococcosis (hydatidosis, hydatid disease)

It is caused by echinococcus granulosus

Diagnosis:

Investigations show a raised eosinophil count; serological tests, such as ELISA and immunoelectrophoresis, point towards the diagnosis. Ultrasonography and CT scan are the investigations of choice

FNAC should never be done before surgery as it can spill out and can cause dissemination or leakage of the cyst can cause anaphylaxis reaction.

Treatment:

  • Usually, no surgical intervention is required in the milder and responsive form, medical therapy is more than enough. Medical therapy includes tab. Albendazole
  • But in later stages surgical interventions are required which are in short described as PAIR (puncture, aspiration, injection and reaspiration). This is done after adequate drug treatment with albendazole.

choices.text: May need amputation in severe cases

questions.text: True regarding frostbite:
questions.solution:
• Frostbite occurs when a part of the body freezes. The cells are disrupted and the tissue dies.
  • It commonly involves the fngers, toes, cheeks, the tip of the nose and the ears. When frozen the tissue feels hard and cannot be indented.
  • Immersion injury is a cold injury that does not involve actual freezing of the tissue and is commonly caused by prolonged immersion in cold water (hence trench foot).

Management:

  • The initial treatment is with rapid rewarming in a bath at 42°C.
  • Warming should be gentle as the heat used may actually cause a burn.
  • Rehydration with warm fluids and use of non-steroidal anti-inflammatory(NSAIDS) drugs such as ibuprofen are beneficial.
  • The injured area should be kept clean and dry and efforts made to prevent further injury, as well as to prevent infection, while rewarming and administration of fluids antibiotics should be given in order to prevent localized infection turning into sepsis.
  • Definitive surgery to excise dead tissue can be left for many months.
  • Recent developments, such as the use of tissue plasminogen activator and nerve blocks, show promising results in reducing amputations, but have to be started within 24 hours and are seldom possible in the field.

questions.text: X-ray given, all the cases of blunt trauma chest. In which of them further investigation is required before inserting ICD?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenarios are blunt or penetrating depending on the nature of injury to the thorax depicted given xray presenting in the emergency department.

Patient require immediate ICD insertion are:

  • Pneumothorax
  • Hemothorax
  • Pleural effusion

ICD is contraindicated in:

  • In Diaphragmatic injury use of icd can deteriorate the health of the patient without further imaging as chest tube can perforate the viscera and can cause pneumoperitoneum as well as pneumomediastinum aggravating the patient's condition .
  • Management of a flail chest should include these areas of concern; maintaining adequate ventilation, fluid management, pain management, and management of the unstable chest wall. Ventilation should be maintained with oxygen and non-invasive ventilation when possible. Invasive mechanical ventilation is used only when other methods fail and extubation should be attempted as early as possible

In the above 2 condition of diaphragmatic hernia and flail chest injury, CT thorax need to be done before inserting ICD

Management via chest tube is as shown in diagram below

questions.text: Which of the following is not a perineal approach for rectal prolapse surgery
questions.solution:
In rectal prolapse surgery the approaches are as follows:

Perineal approach

  • Thiersch's operation. In this procedure, a steel wire, or silastic or nylon tape, is placed around the anal canal. It has become largely obsolete owing to problems with chronic perineal sepsis, anal stenosis and obstructed defecation, but may be used to augment perineal repair in cases of severe pelvic floor
  • Delorme's operation. In this procedure, the rectal mucosa is stripped circumferentially from the rectum over the length of the prolapse. This operation may be preferred in patients with short segment full rectal prolapse, but recurrence rates are high, in the region of 30% over 5 years.
  • Altemeier's procedure. In this procedure, the rectum is prolapsed through the anal canal and a full thickness resection performed, incorporating any associated colonic prolapse. It is often complicated by poor bowel control with faecal soiling secondary to loss of the rectal reservoir. Recurrence rates range from 0% to 20%.

Abdominal approach

The principle of all abdominal operations for rectal prolapse is to fx the rectum in its normal anatomical position. E.g. Well's procedure, Ripstein procedure, fryman goldberg (resection of sigmoid)

The advantages of a perineal approach include minimal postoperative pain, early mobility and low levels of morbidity
